[[File:Tahrir Square on April 1 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on April 1, 2011]]
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''', protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protestors gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. Nonetheless reports emerged of civilian and police casualties.
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''', protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protestors gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. Nonetheless reports emerged of civilian and police casualties.
Line 229: Line 230:
'''23 March 2011''': The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] orders a law criminalizing protests and strikes. Under the new law, anyone organizing or calling for a protest will be sentenced to jail and/or a fine of LE500,000 (~100,000 USD).<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 | date = 23 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Masri Al Youm }}</ref>
'''23 March 2011''': The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] orders a law criminalizing protests and strikes. Under the new law, anyone organizing or calling for a protest will be sentenced to jail and/or a fine of LE500,000 (~100,000 USD).<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 | date = 23 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Masri Al Youm }}</ref>
â
'''1 April 2011''': The '''"Save the Revolution"''' day, Thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square on Friday for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egyptâs Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=2011-04-01 |accessdate=2011-04-02}}</ref>. As an April's fools joke, the Interim Egyptian government announced that Mubarak was returning to power.
+
'''1 April 2011''': The '''"Save the Revolution"''' day; Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square on Friday for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egyptâs Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=2011-04-01 |accessdate=2011-04-02}}</ref>. As an April's fools joke, the Interim Egyptian government announced that Mubarak was returning to power.
